contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Judah refers to its inhabitants. Alternate translation: "the people of Judah have gone into exile" or "the people of Judah have been taken into a foreign land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah has gone into exile

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jerusalem" refers to the people who live there. The phrase "call to mind" is an idiom. Alternate translation: "the people of Jerusalem will remember" or "Jerusalem will remember" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Jerusalem will call to mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers the control of the enemy army. Alternate translation: "When the adversary conquered and captured her people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: When her people fell into the hand of the adversary

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fire" represents pain and "bones" represents one's inner being. Alternate translation: "has sent pain into my bones" or "has sent pain into my inner being" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: has sent fire into my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: "given me over into the hands of my enemies." Here their enemies' control is represented by their "hands." Alternate translation: "given my over to the control of my enemies" or "let my enemies defeat me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: given me over into their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" refers to his descendants, that is Israel. Alternate translation: "around Jacob's descendants should be their adversaries" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: around Jacob should be his adversaries

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "sword" represents the enemy. Alternate translation: "the enemy kills a mother's children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword bereaves a mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the towns of Jacob" refers to the towns where his descendants lived. Alternate translation: "all the towns of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: all the towns of Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Lord's protection is represented by his "right hand." Alternate translation: "stopped protecting us from our enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: withdrawn his right hand from before the enemy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Jacob" refers to the places where his descendants lived. Alternate translation: "Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Lord caused Israel's enemies to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. Alternate translation: "He has caused the place of the solemn assembly to be destroyed" or "He has caused their enemies to destroy the place of the solemn assembly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He has destroyed the place of the solemn assembly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemy's "hand" refers to the enemy's control. Alternate translation: "He has allowed the enemy to capture the walls of her palaces" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He has given over the walls of her palaces into the hand of the enemy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh chose to have the wall destroyed and caused Jerusalem's enemy to destroy it. He did not destroy it himself. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh decided to destroy the city wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name of Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the daughter of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question is used as a request for something to eat. The children are telling their mother that they are hungry. The phrase "grain and wine" represents food and drink. This question may be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "Give us something to eat and drink." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Where is grain and wine?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "horn" (that is, an animal horn) represents strength. Alternate translation: "he has increased the power of your enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he has lifted up the horn of your enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh allowing the poeple to be slaughtered as if he killed them himself. Alternate translation: "you allowed them to be slaughtered" or "you allowed this to happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you have slaughtered them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people the author fears are referred to as his "terrors." Alternate translation: "the attackers I was afraid of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: my terrors

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being "under the rod" represents being beaten with a rod. The author speaks of God's punishment as if God had beaten him with a rod. Alternate translation: "because Yahweh was very angry and has beaten me with a rod" or "because Yahweh was very angry and has punished me severely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: under the rod of Yahweh's fury

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "turned his hand against me" represents attacking him. The author speaks of God causing bad things to happen to him as if God had attacked him. Alternate translation: "he has attacked me" or "he has caused many bad things to happen to me, like someone who attacks a person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he turned his hand against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the heart represents desire or pleasure, and afflicting from the heart represents afflicting with pleasure. Alternate translation: "For it does not make him happy to afflict people" or "He does not take pleasure in afflicting people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: For he does not afflict from his heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doing something "in the presence of the Most High" represents doing it while knowing that God sees it. Alternate translation: "knowing that the Most High sees it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: in the presence of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses this rhetorical question to teach that both calamities and good things happen only because God has commanded them to happen. Alternate translation: "It is only from the mouth of the Most High that both calamities and the good come." or "It is only because the Most High has commanded it that both calamities and good things happen." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it not from the mouth of the Most High that both calamities and the good come?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mouth" represents what God says or commands. Alternate translation: "from the command of the Most High" or "because the Most High has commanded it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from the mouth of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "My eyes" represents what he sees. Alternate translation: "What I see causes me to grieve" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My eyes cause me grief

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's name represents his character, and here, "called on your name" represents trusting God's character and calling on him for help. Alternate translation: "I called to you for help" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: I called on your name

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents what he said. Alternate translation: "You heard my words" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You heard my voice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "close your ear" represents refusing to listen. Alternate translation: "Do not refuse to listen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not close your ear

contextId.occurrenceNote: People often come near to a person they help. Here "came near" represents helping the man. Alternate translation: "you helped me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You came near

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the lips represent what his enemies say. Alternate translation: "The words ... of my enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The lips ... of my enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "heart" is a metonym that represents their attitudes and emotions, and being "shameless" means not feeling ashamed of their sins even though they should. Their not being ashamed would give even more reason for God to punish them. Alternate translation: "You will let them feel no shame for their sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: You will let their hearts be shameless

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "from under the heavens" represents everywhere on earth. Alternate translation: "wherever they are on earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: from under the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. See how you translated this in [Lamentations 2:11](../02/11.md). Alternate translation: "my people have" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the daughter of my people has

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here this phrase is a metonym for luxurious, expensive, and comfortable clothing, at least some of which was probably scarlet. Alternate translation: "luxurious clothing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: scarlet clothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. See how you translated this in [Lamentations 2:11](../02/11.md). Alternate translation: "my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the daughter of my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: People sometimes rub and twist their hands when they are worried and cannot fix something, so wringing the hands here represents worrying. The word "her" refers to Jerusalem, which was called "the daughter of my people." Alternate translation: "no one was worried about her" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: no hands were wrung for her

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "sword" represents an enemy's attack. It can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Those whom enemy soldiers have killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who have been killed by the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hunger" represents starvation. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "those who starved to death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymyand figs-activepassive]] and
contextId.glQuote: those killed by hunger

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "harvest from the field" is a metonym that represents food to eat. Lack of food is spoken of here as if it were a sword that pierces people. Alternate translation: "who died because there was not enough food to eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: pierced by the lack of any harvest from the field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic name for Jerusalem, which is spoken of here as if it were a woman. See how you translated this in [Lamentations 2:11](../02/11.md). Alternate translation: "my people were" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the daughter of my people was

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents God causing Israel's enemies to start a fire in Jerusalem. Alternate translation: "He caused a fire to start in Zion" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: He kindled a fire in Zion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both the priests and the prophets were guilty of murder. Here "shed the blood" represents murder. Alternate translation: "who have murdered the righteous" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: who have shed the blood of the righteous

contextId.occurrenceNote: "defiled by the blood that they shed." Possible meanings are 1) the blood was on their clothes or 2) "blood" is a metonym for murder. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: defiled by that blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "watch over them" represents being concerned about them and helping them. Alternate translation: "he does not care about them anymore" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he does not watch over them anymore

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their eyes failing represents their seeking and not being able to find what they were looking for. These two phrases together emphasize that they were trying hard to find help. Alternate translation: "We continued looking, but we could not find anyone to help us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Our eyes failed, looking in vain for help

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "our steps" represents where they went. Alternate translation: "Our enemies followed us everywhere we went" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: They followed our steps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "iniquities" represents the punishment received because of their ancestors' sins. Alternate translation: "we bear the punishment for their sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: we bear their iniquities

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" refers to control. Alternate translation: "to rescue us from their control" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: to deliver us from their hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bread" refers to food in general. Alternate translation: "food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here robbers with swords are represented by their "swords." Alternate translation: "because there are robbers in the wilderness who kill others with swords" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: because of the sword in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "We no longer wear flowers on our heads for celebrations" or 2) The "crown" represents their king and their "head" represents a place of authority over the people. Alternate translation: "We no longer have a king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The crown has fallen from our head

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "heart" represents a person's emotions. This speaks of a person being discouraged as if their emotions were sick. Alternate translation: "Because of this we are discouraged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For this our heart has become sick

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sitting on the throne represents ruling as king. Alternate translation: "rule as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: sit upon your throne
